posts.name: Ryan
posts.cooked: Our team doesn’t usually color our robot but has been considering anodizing aluminum for future seasons due to its relatively straightforward process using items available in our lab. Is there an advantage to anodizing parts instead of powder coating, and how does it affect bearing tolerances?

link_counts.title: A DIY Step-by-Step Guide on How to Anodize Aluminum | SendCutSend

posts.name: diego
posts.cooked: Powder coating done by a non-professional can result in uneven thickness, so results may vary depending on the skill level. Inspect and fill any bearing holes if possible. Our team plans to perform spray-painting next year, as we have found that it yields a good appearance when done correctly and remains relatively affordable. Consider this option as well.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Personally, I’d never attempt DIY anodizing. Sulfuric acid, lye, and lead, all exposed? Plus figuring out how you safely—and legally—dispose of the leftovers. Powder coating or spray painting is much easier and safer to DIY.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: They are not something I would let kids be around, but there are standard procedures for neutralizing bases and acids—it’s why we’re all dragging boxes of baking soda from one end of the country to the other. Most of you are too young to remember the days before sealed maintenance-free car batteries—you’d have to measure your acid and water level and strength and potentially top it up.

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: Anodizing, for FIRST Robotics Competition purposes, has no impact on weight or tolerances. That being said, as previously mentioned, the process involves a lot of nasty chemicals and is not something FIRST Robotics Competition teams would do in house.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: And an awful lot of those chemicals are restricted in California, IIRC. Rattle-can with proper surface preparation is the way I'd suggest.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: Two additional options are available that are lightweight and durable. Cerakote.com is a global leader in thin-film ceramic coatings, offering specialized finishes for automotive, aerospace, industrial, consumer electronics, sports, and fitness applications. Their services include browsing a gallery and locating a certified applicator. Another option is duracoatfirearmfinishes.com.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

link_counts.title: Cerakote.com - Global Leader in Thin-Film Ceramic Coatings | Cerakote

posts.name: Co-Head Mentor 3658
posts.cooked: My teams have built every robot that I have been part of for the last six seasons. I have a DIY powder coating station in my garage. I constructed a powder coating oven from an old hot dog warmer previously used in a high school cafeteria. While we haven’t found powder coating particularly challenging, it requires practice and is relatively affordable. Despite all this, I’ve always believed that hot rods or stunning car designs have exceptional paint jobs, and I think the same applies to robots. Over the past three years, my teams have consistently won Quality (including two awards this season) and Industrial Design awards annually. These achievements aren’t solely due to powder coating but also highlight the importance of the robots’ colors, as noted by judges in each award win. This suggests that powder coating plays a significant role. Conventional painting methods, often referred to as "rattle-canning," are something I rarely use and can appear lackluster, leading to flaking. I strongly encourage teams to master the art of powder coating—awards truly reflect the quality of the work!

reply_to_user.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Chase Eid
posts.cooked: Maxtube works well with paint. Its manufacturing process creates tiny grooves in aluminum surfaces, allowing paint to adhere more effectively than on unsanded sheet metal.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: I don’t deny that powder coating is great—it is. I am just offering options. Cerakote offers a “cold” series (air dry) for teams that don’t have oven options, with a difference in cure time. They also provide different series for those who have or prefer oven-cured options. I don’t work for them, nor have I used their products personally. EDIT: Cerakote requires only about a 1-mil (0.001-inch) coating, which is very minimal.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked: Cerakote air cure takes hours to be tack-free and around 5 days to cure. Plus, it smells like burning urine cakes and poses a severe inhalation risk. I spray Cerakote for both fun and profit, but I wouldn’t suggest it for robot parts, even if the test parts I did looked amazing. Similarly, I wouldn’t recommend anodizing aluminum in-house. Even after applying the necessary chemicals, you still need to dye and seal the parts. On the other hand, you can DIY anodized titanium using water, baking soda, and a power source of 10-120 volts at less than 1A. We successfully made titanium wire turn blue by using approximately 30 volts. The rest of our robot was rattle-canned after some preparation work. While it looks great on the webcast, it doesn’t hold up as well up close in the pits. This tradeoff of time, money, and results seems reasonable for many teams.

posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked: You can also use vinyl to wrap parts, similar to car and bus wraps. While it may not be as durable as some alternatives, it can still be used with patterned prints or solid designs. Additionally, wrapping certain parts of a robot can be done after they have already been attached.

posts.name: Ardiano Works
posts.cooked: "Was there any surface preparation done on this Air Cure Cerakote? I didn’t even know this exists. We had to perform an oxide blast, which required the use of personal protective equipment and specific filtration systems. After that, we wiped everything down and applied the spray, then moved the item into the oven."

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked: It has to be super clean, bare metal for optimal results. Degrease, sandblast or abrade, propane torch on some parts, and degrease again. You can wait a minute for steel, but aluminum oxidizes so quickly you really want to spray it as soon as its natural oxide layer is removed. It goes on so thin that you also have to be 100% happy with the surface finish. Cerakote hides nothing.

posts.name: JohnD 3322
posts.cooked: Check for a local shop that does anodizing. There’s a good chance they’ll offer a 'in-kind' sponsorship by providing free anodizing. Don’t expect a quick turnaround, so we typically send a few tubes early in the season and then machine them after being anodized. This process gives a good two-tone finish with shiny holes, and there’s always a Sharpie available if you need to touch up the colors.

posts.name: 829 The Digital Goats Official Curmudgeon.
posts.cooked: Anodizing does remove a tinny layer of material. The racks used for the parts become too thin and need to be replaced. However, if a part is anodized many times, tolerances won't be significantly affected. We're fortunate to have a reliable anodizing company here in Indianapolis that serves many central Indiana teams. A big shoutout goes to Colors Inc.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
Anodizing does remove a tinny layer of material, but it does not significantly alter the overall dimensions of the part. Instead, it converts some of the base material into an oxide layer, causing the part to expand slightly outward. This process is generally minimal, often measured in microns, making it imperceptible to most users. However, in cases involving materials like titanium, the expansion can still affect critical components such as pin and bearing press-fits or bolt hole sizes, potentially causing misalignments or gaps.  

The confusion likely arises from mistaking the etching process, which prepares parts for anodizing, for the anodizing process itself. Etching removes material to account for the expected growth during anodization, ensuring the finished part matches the original dimensions. In some cases, parts may be machined slightly underspec, relying on the oxide layer growth to bring them back into tolerance or closer to the midpoint of the spec range.  

Racks used for anodizing, particularly those made of less durable materials, can sometimes degrade over time due to chemical exposure, especially if they are used in certain etching baths. This is why manufacturers often opt for more robust materials like titanium for their durability and resistance to corrosion in such environments.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: I would suggest it for robot parts, even if the test parts I did looked amazing. Wouldn't, right?

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked: Cerakote air cure takes hours to be tack-free and around 5 days to cure. Plus, it smells like burning urinal cakes. See, this is why they won't let you do marketing! What a great description. To stay on topic, I'm all in on rattle cans—90% of the bang with a super low entry point regarding skill and equipment requirements.
